node.title: Jurors weigh fate of officer fired after Breonna Taylor raid
node.description: Brett Hankison has been charged with three counts of wanton endangerment, punishable by one to five years in prison.
node.content: ["The fate of the only officer charged in the raid that killed Breonna Taylor went to a jury on Thursday after a prosecutor said he couldn't have seen a shooter before firing wildly into her apartment and endangering her next-door neighbors.", "Brett Hankison has been charged with three counts of wanton endangerment, punishable by one to five years in prison, for firing shots during the raid that went through Taylor's side door and window and into the next-door apartment where a couple and small child lived.", "Hankison, 45, testified during the trial that he saw a muzzle flash from Taylor's darkened hallway after police burst through the door and thought officers were under heavy fire, so he quickly wheeled around a corner and sprayed 10 bullets, hoping to end the threat.", "But prosecutors in closing arguments Tuesday cast doubt on what Hankison said he saw, challenging whether he could have looked through Taylor's front door when police broke it open with a battering ram.", "\"He was never in the doorway,\" Assistant Kentucky Attorney General Barbara Maines Whaley told jurors in her closing argument. \"His wanton conduct could have multiplied one tragic death, Breonna Taylor, his wanton conduct could have multiplied her death by three, easily.\"", "Whaley reminded the jury Thursday that none of the other officers who testified recalled Hankison being in the doorway before the gunfire began. All the shells from his weapon were found in the parking lot, among a row of cars.", "She said while other officers were in the line of fire of a single shot fired by Taylor's boyfriend, Hankison was \"over here, shooting wildly through sliding glass doors covered with vertical blinds and drapes.\"", "Hankison's attorneys never contested the ballistics evidence that showed he fired 10 times into the side of the apartment complex. The former narcotics detective, fired by Louisville Police for shooting blindly during the raid, admitted to firing through Taylor's patio door and bedroom window, but said he did so to save his fellow officers. Asked if he did anything wrong that night, he said \"absolutely not.\"", "Hankison testified he believed the gunshot he saw at the door was from a long rifle or AR-15, and his fellow officers were \"being executed\" at Taylor's front door.", "Defense attorney Stewart Mathews told the jury Thursday morning that Hankison thought he was doing the right thing in what he thought was a gun battle, and that he's not a criminal who belongs in prison.", "\"He did what he thought he had to do in that instant. This all happened in such a short span,\" Mathews said.", "A 20-year veteran K9 officer assigned to handle a drug-sniffing dog during the raid, Hankison said he was positioned behind the officer with a battering ram, and could see the shadowy silhouette of a person \"in a shooting stance\" with what looked like an AR-15 rifle as Taylor's door swung open.", "No long gun was found - only the handgun of Taylor's boyfriend Kenneth Walker, who told Louisville Police investigators he thought intruders were breaking in. Investigators determined Walker fired the shot that passed through the leg of Sergeant John Mattingly, who along with Officer Myles Cosgrove, returned fire. A total of 32 rounds were fired by police. Walker wasn't hit.", "\"I don't think I ever heard so many gunshots all the same time,\" Walker told \"CBS Mornings\" co-host Gayle King in October 2020. \"I've never been to war but I assume\u00a0 that's what war probably sounds like.\"", "Whaley said other officers next to Cosgrove and Mattingly chose not to fire, and there was no evidence of any shots from a long rifle at the scene.", "\"Nobody got shot with an AR because there was never one,\" she said.", "The killing of Taylor loomed over the trial, though prosecutors insisted in opening statements that the case wasn't about her death or the police decisions that led to the March 13, 2020, raid. Jurors were shown a single image of her body, barely discernible at the end of the hallway.", "Taylor, a 26-year-old emergency medical technician who had been settling down for bed when officers broke through her door, was shot multiple times and died at the scene.", "Kentucky Attorney General Daniel Cameron 's prosecutors asked a grand jury to indict Hankison on charges of endangering Taylor's neighbors, but declined to seek charges against any officers involved in Taylor's death. Protesters who had walked the streets for months were outraged.", "Taylor's name, along with George Floyd and Ahmaud Arbery \u2014 Black men who died in encounters with police and White pursuers \u2014 became rallying cries during racial justice protests seen around the world in 2020.", "The jury of 10 men and five women was selected after several days of questioning from a pool expanded to about 250 people. Before deliberations, the jury was reduced to 8 men and 4 women after three alternates were dismissed. The judge declined to release details about their race or ethnicity."]
